articles.headline: Leaders Call for Peace as Mideast Talks Begin
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority appeared together with President Obama.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority appeared together with President Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama began his Middle East peace initiative on Wednesday, as the Israeli and Palestinian leaders committed to work to end the conflict that has endured for six decades.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Israeli Peace Effort Rests on Netanyahu
articles.snippet: The Israeli prime minister believes that only someone like himself, with his hawkish credentials, has the will and support to produce lasting peace with the Palestinians.
articles.abstract: The Israeli prime minister believes that only someone like himself, with his hawkish credentials, has the will and support to produce lasting peace with the Palestinians.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — David Rubinger, one of Israel’s best-known photojournalists and a man firmly on the political left, cast his ballot last year for Benjamin Netanyahu for prime minister, the first time he had ever voted for the right-leaning Likud Party.

articles.headline: Of Two Minds About Books
articles.snippet: The book business tries to serve two readers, the one who loves the tactile page and the one who loves the digital ease.
articles.abstract: The book business tries to serve two readers, the one who loves the tactile page and the one who loves the digital ease.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Auriane and Sebastien de Halleux are at sharp odds over “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” but not about the plot. The problem is that she prefers the book version, while he reads it on his iPad. And in this literary dispute, the couple says, it’s ne’er the twain shall meet.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Your Own Hot Spot, and Cheap
articles.snippet: Virgin Mobile’s MiFi is nearly like the ones offered by Sprint and Verizon but with three exceptions: an unlimited data plan, no contract and a $40-a-month service fee.
articles.abstract: Virgin Mobile’s MiFi is nearly like the ones offered by Sprint and Verizon but with three exceptions: an unlimited data plan, no contract and a $40-a-month service fee.
articles.lead_paragraph: Someday, they’ll build wireless Internet into every building, just the way they build in running water, heat and electricity today. Someday, we won’t have to drive around town looking for a coffee shop when we need to check our e-mail.

articles.headline: Child’s Ordeal Shows Risks of Psychosis Drugs for Young
articles.snippet: Powerful drugs are given to young children despite a lack of study on how they affect development.
articles.abstract: Powerful drugs are given to young children despite a lack of study on how they affect development.
articles.lead_paragraph: OPELOUSAS, La. — At 18 months, Kyle Warren started taking a daily antipsychotic drug on the orders of a pediatrician trying to quell the boy’s severe temper tantrums.

articles.headline: Maker of Botox Settles Inquiry
articles.snippet: Allergan agreed to pay $600 million to settle charges that it illegally promoted and sold Botox for unapproved uses.
articles.abstract: Allergan agreed to pay $600 million to settle charges that it illegally promoted and sold Botox for unapproved uses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Allergan, the maker of Botox, agreed on Wednesday to pay $600 million to settle charges that it illegally promoted and sold the drug through 2005 for unapproved uses like treating headaches.

articles.headline: In Somali Civil War, Both Sides Embrace Pirates
articles.snippet: After years of not getting sucked into the messy civil war on land, Somalia’s pirate gangs are taking sides — both sides.
articles.abstract: After years of not getting sucked into the messy civil war on land, Somalia’s pirate gangs are taking sides — both sides.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOBYO, Somalia  Ismail Haji Noor, a local government official, recently arrived in this notorious pirate den with a simple message: we need your help.

articles.headline: Feud With Palin in Background of Alaska Upset
articles.snippet: Sarah Palin reveled in the primary upset of Senator Lisa Murkowski, but tensions began well before.
articles.abstract: Sarah Palin reveled in the primary upset of Senator Lisa Murkowski, but tensions began well before.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE  The message might have seemed gracious, on its face.

articles.headline: Burger King Has Suitors From Brazil
articles.snippet: Burger King Holdings is in advanced talks to sell itself to 3G Capital, a Brazilian investment firm.
articles.abstract: Burger King Holdings is in advanced talks to sell itself to 3G Capital, a Brazilian investment firm.
articles.lead_paragraph: Burgers and beer  an American meal if there ever was one  could soon have a distinctly Brazilian flavor.
articles.byline: By Peter Lattman and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Toyota Feels Exchange-Rate Pinch as Rivals Gain
articles.snippet: For all the turmoil over Toyota's wave of recalls, the world's largest automaker may face a bigger problem: the surging yen.
articles.abstract: For all the turmoil over Toyota's wave of recalls, the world's largest automaker may face a bigger problem: the surging yen.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — For all the turmoil over Toyota’s wave of recalls, the company, the world’s largest automaker, may face a bigger problem: the surging yen.

articles.headline: Discounts Help Lift Back-to-School Sales
articles.snippet: Retail sales rose 3.3 percent, more than forecast. But the results are measured against a weak month a year ago.
articles.abstract: Retail sales rose 3.3 percent, more than forecast. But the results are measured against a weak month a year ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: Back-to-school season started off on sale, with retailers receiving new merchandise in August, and then marking it down to get it out the door.

articles.headline: Depositors Panic Over Bank Crisis in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: A bank official tried to calm fears of a meltdown at Kabul Bank, while depositors were unable to withdraw money.
articles.abstract: A bank official tried to calm fears of a meltdown at Kabul Bank, while depositors were unable to withdraw money.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  One of the principal owners of the Afghan bank at the center of an accelerating financial crisis here said depositors had withdrawn $180 million in the past two days. He predicted a “revolution” in the country’s financial system unless the Afghan government and the United States moved quickly to help stabilize the bank.
